name: Nashville
fun_fact: Fun fact: Nashville hot chicken was invented in the 1930s as revenge by Thornton Prince's jealous girlfriend who doused his fried chicken in cayenne pepper to punish him for a night out - but he loved it so much he opened a restaurant!

hero_dishes.name: Nashville Hot Chicken
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fried chicken coated in a fiery cayenne pepper paste, traditionally served on white bread with pickles. Heat levels range from 'Southern' (no heat) to 'Shut the Cluck Up' (extreme heat).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in the 1930s when Thornton Prince's scorned lover tried to teach him a lesson by making his beloved fried chicken unbearably spicy. The plan backfired - he loved it! Prince opened his chicken shack and the rest is culinary history. His great-niece AndrÃ© Prince Jeffries now runs Prince's Hot Chicken, which received a James Beard American Classic Award.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Prince's Hot Chicken (the original since 1936), Hattie B's Hot Chicken (multiple locations since 2012, famous for their heat levels and pimento mac and cheese sides), Bolton's Spicy Chicken & Fish

hero_dishes.name: Meat and Three
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Southern plate featuring one meat and three vegetable sides - a Nashville lunch staple
hero_dishes.origin_story: Classic working-class lunch tradition from Nashville's honky tonk days

signature_drinks.name: Sweet Tea
signature_drinks.description: Ice-cold black tea sweetened with copious amounts of sugar - the unofficial beverage of the South
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold in mason jars or tall glasses, often refilled for free at restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Tennessee Whiskey
signature_drinks.description: Smooth whiskey filtered through sugar maple charcoal, distinct from bourbon
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Neat, on the rocks, or in classic cocktails at honky tonks along Broadway

food_culture_notes: Nashville's 'Honky Tonk Highway' on Lower Broadway features live music from 10am to 3am with no cover charge - four blocks of non-stop country music
The city earned the nickname 'Music City' and has been home to the Grand Ole Opry since 1925
Tootsie's Orchid Lounge (opened 1960) got its famous purple exterior when a painter accidentally used the wrong color
Nashville was the first to have electric lighting in the South and is home to a full-scale replica of the Parthenon in Centennial Park
Hot chicken is traditionally eaten with white bread and pickles to help cut the heat

landmarks: Ryman Auditorium (Mother Church of Country Music)
Broadway's neon-lit honky tonks with purple facades
Music City Walk of Fame stars
atmosphere: Neon-lit honky tonk bars spilling live music onto the streets
Street performers with guitars and cowboy boots
BBQ smoke and hot chicken aromas
Southern hospitality with a rockabilly edge

Cayenne red and fiery orange from hot chicken
Deep golden brown of fried chicken crust
White bread and bright green pickles (classic hot chicken presentation)
